OK here's a compound idea that I think should produce some interesting results. First, drop some dry ice into a water balloon. Then, fill it partway with super glue. Finally, drop it in liquid nitrogen before the CO2 has much time to expand, hopefully reversing the inflation before the balloon pops. Just long enough to freeze the exterior hard enough to form a shell of frozen cyanoacrylate. Assuming that all goes according to plan, make a few incisions on the balloon, then drop the frozen super glue/dry ice ball into hot borax solution.

With the hot vs cold borax solutions being more and less reactive respectively I imagine that it's at least partially caused by the fact that water can (typically) dissolve more of a solute when at a higher temperature. This is actually used in industry and research to super-saturate water-based solutions at times. So, with more borax being dissolved into solution at higher temperatures, the solution itself SHOULD be more reactive.

I know you like the hot borax because of the speed of the reaction, but I rather liked seeing the reaction happen slower in the cold. Next you should do ice water or if there is something that dissolves borax with a lower freezing point: then do that and see how slow you can get this reaction to happen.

The interesting thing is that the slower it cures, the stronger it is as a bulk polymer, but the weaker it is as a glue.  The more mobile anions you coat a surface with, the less effective superglue will be upon that surface.  If you make a surface that is anionic it will stick best to superglue.
